highlights: A significant storm is impacting this region. A high degree of caution is advised for the next couple of days.
confidence: Fair -  Timing, track, or intensity of incoming weather is uncertain on Wednesday
avalancheSummary: We're still pretty light on info from the field but nothing significant to report form the last 24 hours. I got a photo of the skier triggered 2.5 in Rogers Pass from last Friday and I sure wouldn't have wanted to be tangled up in that one. I'll see if I can get permission to post it and you can take look for yourself--check our photo gallery under the library tab and see if it's there. I did talk to one of our field teams in the South Rockies and they could hear natural avalanches running in the Lizard Range. I know that's quite far from here but they're in the same weather pattern so it might be relevant or a precursor. I think we're in for a cycle that will probably start Monday night or Tuesday morning and could last for a few days if the weather forecast is accurate.
snowpackSummary: On average, snowpack depths are looking like 80-100cm at treeline and probably 150 in the alpine as of end of the weekend. That said, distribution is highly variable, so on a small scale you'll likely see bare ground beside areas with well over 200cm of snow while on a larger scale, one mountain or drainage may have significantly more or less than the next. By the time you read this, the current storm will have been going for 12-24 hours so snow depths will have increased accordingly and the upper part of the snowpack will consist largely of new storm snow in sheltered areas and new wind slabs in exposed locations. How much and how widespread this condition is will vary from northern and eastern areas (perhaps somewhat less) to south and western sections (likely somewhat more). I expect the storm and windslabs to be reactive for the next few days but I'll update tomorrow if I get more solid data. There's some potential problems at the old/new interface and in the mid-pack including thin crusts and the November surface hoar, on which I think there is now general agreement that it's November 7th and is a persistent weak layer. It may not last as long as true winter surface hoar but it's down 100cm and has been around for 2 weeks so I guess a PWL it is. Even if these layers seem like they've died down a bit in the last few days, I suspect they'll reactivate in the next couple of days, perhaps not on a widespread basis but certainly locally on specific terrain (e.g. especially where no previous activity occurred). The deep snowpack is a bit of a mixed bag. I'm thinking probably some facets in shallow areas, more rounded in deeper locations and in many cases these layers will be moist at and near the ground. This is a general overview--I'm hesitant to get too specific this early in the season when data is sparse and there's so much variability. If you think I'm out to lunch and want to set me straight: forecaster@avalanche.ca.
weatherForecast: A strong system is in the region and forecast to continue overnight Monday and into Tuesday. The southern sections may be more like the South Columbia so you may want to look at my South Columbia forecast if the weather seems more intense and lasts longer than noted here. By end of the day Monday, significant accumulation of new snow will have occurred. Monday night: Heavy snow, winds SW 50-70, freezing levels rising to 1800m. Tuesday: the storm tapers off, light to moderate precipitation and winds S 60-100. Freezing levels rise overnight Monday to become 1200-1500m Tuesday. Wednesday: Dryer and freezing levels at surface again but strong SW winds continue. Thursday: Cool, light winds, and dry. This system has proven to be quite unpredictable so there's a fair amount of uncertainty so check back tomorrow for an update.

problems.comment: New snow, warming temperatures, and wind are a perfect recipe for an avalanche cycle, which is probably already occurring in some areas. At lower elevations watch for avalanches running full path from above.
New windslabs are likely forming and I expect they'll be sensitive to natural and human triggering by Tuesday morning.
The surface hoar causing this problem has been quiet lately but I'm pretty sure it will wake up as the new snow accumulates and windloading occurs.

avalancheSummary: The natural cycle in Glacier National Park continues with several size 3 avalanches reported this morning. Without seeing them with my own eyes or hearing about them first hand, I'm as sure as I can be that there's lots of activity all over the North Columbia. Don't get fooled by a lull in the action--the snowpack is in a very dynamic state right now so natural activity will likely ebb and flow but human triggering will remain likely even when naturals taper off.
snowpackSummary: On average, I'm guessing nearly 100cm of new snow has been added to the alpine snowpack in the last few days. Figure half that at treeline. Below treeline it's probably a mixed bag of rain, slush, and snow depending where you are in the region and elevation. Here's my take, based purely on experience, what little information I have from a few select locations, and recent weather. Snowpack depths are looking like 100-150cm at treeline and probably 250+cm in the alpine. Distribution is likely still pretty variable due to winds and variability in storm track and intensity. On a small scale you'll likely see bare ground beside areas with well over 250+cm of snow while on a larger scale, one mountain or drainage may have significantly more or less than the next. The upper part of the snowpack consists entirely of new storm snow in sheltered areas and new wind slabs in exposed locations, both of which are likely settling rapidly with warm temperatures. I'm pretty certain the storm and wind loaded snow is unstable both at the new/old interface and within the new snow at various levels. How unstable and how long the instability lasts in lulls between systems and after this whole thing ends will relate primarily to temperatures. Click on the forecaster blog link below for a bit more detail on this. These problems are changing by the minute and hour so you need to stay on your toes. Settlement will be occurring in the midpack as well but crusts and the November 7 surface hoar, which could be down as deep as 200cm in some locations, continue to be a concern. If these layers have not been destroyed by previous avalanche activity, my gut tells me they are on the edge of the knifeblade and are capable of producing very large slides. I expect settlement is going on in the deeper layers as well. Still a mixed bag there though, with weaker facetted snow in shallow areas, stronger more rounded in deeper locations, and in many cases these layers will be moist at and near the ground. This is a general overview--I'm hesitant to get too specific this early in the season when data is sparse and there's so much spatial (and now with the ongoing storm, temporal) variability. If you think I'm out to lunch and want to set me straight: forecaster@avalanche.ca.
weatherForecast: Storm, lull, storm, lull, storm... The pattern continues. Successive waves of moderate to heavy precipitation, strong winds, and warm temperatures interspersed with cooler, calmer, dryer, and maybe even somewhat clear spells. I will not even try to be specific about timing right now because it changes every time I look at the models. There's no end in sight, for now it seems the pattern will continue through the weekend--who knows? Most of you are probably hunkered down and waiting it out anyway or staying in non-avalanche terrain--right?

problems.comment: Don't be fooled if it seems things are settling down in lulls between storms: natural activity may come and go but human triggering remains likely for several days yet. Below treeline, watch for avalanches running full path from above.
Old and new windslabs are almost a major player in the avalanche activity I'm quite sure is occurring in this region.
Where it still exists, this layer is now capable of producing very large avalanches.

avalancheSummary: We had a report today from a professional member that flew through the Selkirks south of Revelstoke on Thursday.  Widespread natural activity was observed up to size 3.5 in the alpine that was running full path into the valleys. Some fracture lines appeared to be about 2 metres deep and very wide. In some areas very large avalanches had run out onto low angle terrain.  Most avalanches had initiated between 2200m and 2600m. Avalanches were observed from all aspects, with north and east being the most frequent. This may not be the case in the Monashees,  but until we hear differently that is how I am going to treat that part of the region.
snowpackSummary: Generally we have about 150 cms in the alpine, and treeline has been showing some variability between 50 -150 cms. There are locations in the alpine that have 200 cms plus already. The freezing level went up to about 1900 metres on Wednesday and caused some pretty rapid settlement, followed by below freezing temperatures that have re-frozen the snow pack up to about treeline elevations. The wind has come from the southwest during the last storm, and then strong from the northeast immediately following the storm. Yesterday the wind was strong in the alpine from the east-southeast. We were feeling pretty sure that there was a major avalanche cycle going on in the alpine, that we thought was probably failing on the buried surface hoar layer that has been reported to be down about a metre. Today we received new information from the Selkirks south of Revelstoke that there was indeed a major avalanche cycle up to size 3.5 during the last storm, but it appears that most of the avalanches were sliding on a layer that is near the ground; perhaps a rain crust from October. The slides may have started on the surface hoar layer and then stepped down to the crust. We hope to get some more information soon, as operators start getting out into the field. There is probably a lull in activity today (Friday), but I am hesitant to bring down danger ratings with the limited information that we have. The next storm is forecast for Saturday, and it looks like it is going to come in warm again, maybe up to 2000 metres. I think the "take home" advice from recent activity is that you should be very suspicious of any slopes in the alpine that have not recently avalanched.  If there is a crust of some type down low near the ground, you should be watching out for areas that might re-load with the next storm. Due to the variability of the amounts of snow in different drainages, I think that the absence of recent avalanche activity in an area would concern me as well. These are difficult early season conditions to evaluate. I recommend being very conservative this weekend. It is going to take a few days at least before we see any improvement. Let me know what you think! forecaster@avalanche.ca

snowpackSummary: I still feel like I have more questions than answers in this region. I know that there is generally 200 cms of snow in the alpine. Some areas are bound to have closer to 250 cms. There was a period in early November when the conditions were optimal for the development of surface hoar. By the middle of the month when the first heavy snowfalls arrived, we were getting reports of widespread avalanche activity releasing on buried surface hoar from the few areas that were accessible. The snow has continued to build up in the mountains and the winds have been from strong to very strong from various directions. I suspect that the depth of snow in the alpine and at treeline is quite variable due to these winds re-distributing the snow that was available for transport. Last Thursday we had a report from the south Selkirks that there had been a widespread natural cycle of very large avalanches that appeared to have released very near to the ground. This type of activity would usually be because of some kind of early season crust that is thick enough and hard enough that it has not broken down in the 5-6 weeks since it has been buried. I suspect a rain crust because the avalanche activity was observed from several aspects, mostly north and east. If it is a rain crust, maybe it is limited to the South Selkirks? The warm storm that moved through the interior over the weekend deposited about 40-60 cms of snow. The new snow has been pretty heavy at all but the highest alpine elevations. The freezing level has risen to about 1800 metres, and the wind has been very strong out of the southwest. I would not be surprised to find out that natural avalanche activity has occurred on Sunday. Maybe the added load will cause some more avalanches to release down at the rain crust? If not, the new load and warm temperatures might help to settle the snowpack and promote bonding. If it gets cold, the deep weakness may continue to be a problem for a while.  I suggest giving the snowpack a few days to reveal its secrets. I will feel less uncertain once we have more operators reporting from the field.

problems.comment: Forecast rain up to about 2300 metres should continue to cause loose wet avalanches. New snow above 2300 metre may not bond well to areas that re-freeze before the snow starts falling.
Forecast rain and high freezing levels may cause avalanches to step down to buried crusts. Avalanches that propagate fractures on a crust may be large and destructive.
Recent windslabs on northerly aspects should settle and bond quickly due to the warm daytime temperatures. New windslabs may form due to forecast new snow and southwest winds.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
highlights: Daily bulletins with danger ratings are finished for the season for this region. General advice can be found in the Avalanche Problems section and on the Forecast Details tab below. Additional information can be found in the Forecaster Blog.
avalancheSummary: Spring conditions exist in the region. Avalanches are most likely to occur in response to solar radiation, warm temperatures, and periods of rain. Particularly dangerous conditions may develop during prolonged periods of warming, heavy rain, or on days with no overnight freeze. Under these conditions, surface avalanches may step down and trigger deeper wet slab avalanches. Prolonged warming may also weaken large and destructive cornices. Large cornice releases are dangerous, and may act as a heavy trigger on the slope below. Typically, avalanche activity increases during the day and is at a peak during the afternoon. If it's raining or there was no overnight freeze, avalanche activity can happen at any time.
snowpackSummary: As we transition into spring, the surface layers have a great deal of influence on the snowpack. When there is a solid re-frozen surface crust, travel is fast and easy, and the snowpack is held together by the surface cap. Surface layers and any deeper persistent weak layers are unlikely to fail until the surface cap breaks down from daytime heating. During warm conditions, melt water is able to percolate within the snowpack and cause surface layers and any deeper weak layers to fail. If it cools off and snows, new snow may not bond well to the hard spring crusts, and isolated storm and wind slabs can easily develop.

problems.comment: Loose wet avalanches are most likely on steep slopes as temperatures rise or when there is no overnight freeze. Prolonged exposure to sunshine or rainfall may cause this problem to become more widespread and include low angled slopes.

Prolonged warming may weaken the snowpack and cause wet slab avalanches. These could fail on buried spring crusts, deeply buried persistent weak layers, or on the ground, potentially creating very large avalanches.
